column1: This tab has one table with estimates for alcohol consumption, by age and sex, of persons aged 15 years and over. It ranges from cell A1 to R91.

* estimate has a relative standard error of 25% to 50% and should be used with caution.
** estimate has a relative standard error greater than 50% and is considered too unreliable for general use.
Cells in this table containing data have been randomly adjusted to avoid the release of confidential data. Discrepancies may occur between sums of the component items and totals.
(a) The Australian Adult Alcohol Guideline was released in December 2020 by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). For more information see Methodology.
(b) Sex recorded at birth refers to what was determined by sex characteristics observed at birth or infancy.
(c) The Australian Children Alcohol Guideline recommends people under 18 years of age should not drink alcohol. For more information see Methodology.
(d) Includes persons whose sex recorded at birth was another term (other than male or female).

(e) The Australian Adult Alcohol Guideline recommends persons aged 18 years and over, either drink no more than 10 standard drinks per week or no more than 4 standard drinks on a single day once a month or more often. For more information see Methodology.

(f) At least monthly consumption has been interpreted as consuming 5 or more drinks at least 12 times in the last 12 months. This measure is not directly comparable to single occasion risk interpreted from the NHMRC 2009 Guideline 2. For more information see Methodology.

(g) Includes persons who consumed alcohol in last week but did not exceed guidelines, never consumed alcohol, did not consume alcohol in the last week but did less than 12 months ago, or consumed alcohol 12 or more months ago.
(h) Includes persons who did not remember when they last consumed alcohol.
